Dear Andrea Melendrez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the program manager at triestramc@michigan.gov.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 grabbed and twisted Youth C's arm and pushed her head
against the wall. There are no marks or bruises.
Investigation I notified Complainant, who is also Youth C’s foster care worker,
that I was assigned this joint investigation with Government
Worker 1. Complainant expressed no additional concerns
regarding the facility.
I collaborated with Government Worker 1 via email.
Multiple barriers were encountered related to viewing video of
incident in question. Government Worker 1 and I arrived
unannounced at the facility on 6/16/23 and spoke with Chief
Administrator (CA). CA was already aware of the allegation made
by Complainant on 6/14/23. We requested video footage of the
interaction between Staff 1 and Youth C on 6/14/23. CA told us
she had not viewed the video and does not know how to access
them. She said another individual who works off-site for
Genacross has access to the videos. CA contacted that individual
in our presence and requested the video be accessed and sent to
Government Worker 1 as soon as possible.
Video footage arrived at Government Worker 1’s inbox in 20
separate unmarked pieces. They had to be arranged in
chronological order and viewed separately. Government Worker 1
requested a clearer copy of one of the videos and did not receive
it for two days. I was unable to view the 20 videos on my
computer so Government Worker 1 texted them to my phone. I
was unable to view them in chronological sequence as the
timestamps were too small to read.
Government Worker 1 and I were able to view two or three of the
20 videos together at the facility. One video showed Staff 1
physically struggling with Youth C against a wall and blocking her
2

from moving. Government Worker 1 and I located CA on the
residential unit, asked her to view the video with us and develop a
separation plan for Staff 1 and Youth C. CA said she was unable
to view it because she was working as direct care staff monitoring
two children for the next two hours. Later that afternoon,
Government Worker 1 and I telephoned CA and asked her again
to view the video and develop a separation plan. After viewing it,
CA decided Staff 1 should be placed on administrative leave
pending the outcome of the investigation. I confirmed with
Licensee Designee (LD) that Staff 1 was indeed placed on leave
on 6/16/23.
VIDEO
I viewed videos of the hallway where the incident began around
8:02am. They show Staff 1 and Youth C talking in the hall. Staff 1
is positioned directly in front of Youth C with her back to the
camera. At some point Youth C appears to hit or attempt to hit
Staff 1 but the camera does not show this. Staff 1 responds by
pushing Youth C to the wall with her arms, momentarily pinning
her. The two physically disengage and move together down the
hall. Youth C sits or falls to the floor then stands. Youth C tries to
move past Staff 1, but Staff 1 blocks/pushes into her with her
body. Youth C and Staff 1 are in Youth C’s bedroom alone
together twice - once for 18 seconds and another time for 52
seconds. Other videos show Youth C laying on the floor at the
end of the hallway with Staff 1 standing nearby.
I interviewed Youth C jointly with Government Worker 1. When
asked about her morning routine, she said she usually wakes up
at 8:30am, gets dressed and stays in her room until breakfast is
served. She said breakfast is not served at any certain time.
When asked about Staff 1, Youth C described her as “mean.” “If
we come out (of our rooms) without permission, we get privileges
taken away,” she added. Initially Youth C refused to elaborate.
Given time and support, she said Staff 1 grabbed her arm, pushed
her and hit the middle of her head “really hard” on the wall in her
bedroom. “I told her, ‘You almost broke my head open.’” Youth C
does not have any injuries as a result. However, she said she
does not feel safe with Staff 1 or Former Staff 3. *Note - Former
Staff 3 resigned on 6/14/23 while being investigated for alleged
abuse/neglect (see SIR 2023C0000500).
I interviewed Youth Y jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
been at the facility for 11 months. Youth Y said he comes out of
his room at 9am or whenever breakfast is ready. He did not know
3

what would happen if he tried to come out of his room before
breakfast. Youth Y was unaware of the incident involving Staff 1
and Youth C.
I interviewed Youth B jointly with Government Worker 1. He was
unaware of the incident involving Staff 1 and Youth C.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 on 6/16/23
and 7/7/23. She has worked midnight shift at the facility for one
year and was last trained in CPI physical management in Feb
2023. Staff 1 has no disciplinary write-ups in her file.
Government Worker 1 asked Staff 1 about her interaction with
Youth C on the morning of 6/14/23. She said she and Staff 2
were working. It was between 7:30 – 8:00am when Youth C
asked for the time. Staff 1 redirected her back to her room
because “other kids were still asleep, and it was too early to get
up.”
In the hallway, Staff 1 said “Youth C jumped toward me, went to
hit me and hit me. I stopped her.” Staff 1 put both hands out in
front of herself demonstrating how she stopped Youth C. “Youth
B and Y mocked Youth C and Youth C went to get at them. I
blocked her body with my body…I pushed her in the room…I did
not do anything vicious when I pushed her. I got her in her room
and yes, she fell on the bed. She accused me of hurting her and
throwing her against the wall…said she’d tell her worker. Youth C
slid down the wall and tried to open another kid’s door with her
foot. She told me I ought to quit…like Former Staff 3.” Staff 1
denied ever grabbing Youth C’s arm or hitting her head against
the wall. After the incident Staff 1 said she examined Youth C’s
head and saw no injury.
I asked Staff 1 what justified the single-person physical
interventions she utilized with Youth C. She said “If a youth
attacks me, I can block and deflect…We could not use CPI (two-
person control hold) because there were only two of us and Staff 2
had to stay with Youth Y because he will run. We didn’t have the
luxury of a third staff.” I asked Staff 1 why she physically tried to
move Youth C into her room. She responded, “Because Youth C
was trying to fight Youths Y and B.”
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1 by phone
on 6/23/23. She has worked at the facility for one year. Staff 2
explained what she saw on the morning of 6/14/23. “There are
only two staff (monitoring six youth) before 9am so we try to
4

convince kids to stay in their rooms. Youth C wasn’t wanting to
listen…Youth C was lying on the floor and refused to go to her
room. I saw Staff 1 put her hands on Youth C’s upper arm or
back. It was like she was trying to herd her back into her room. I
saw Youth C swing at Staff 1. I don’t know if she made contact.
Staff 1 told her, ‘You don’t hit staff’.”
Staff 2 said Staff 1 and Youth C went into Youth C’s room for less
than five minutes. “I don’t know exactly what happened. I heard
Youth C say, ‘You pushed me. You almost made me hit my head.
Staff 1 said out loud, ‘You hit your bed not the wall.’ I didn’t know
what to do. I was keeping Youths B and Y occupied (in their
rooms). Staff 1 said it is atypical for a staff person to be alone
with a youth in her room for that length of time.
Analysis Video shows Staff 1 push Youth C and momentarily pin her
against the wall in the hallway. Staff 1 referred to this push as a
block or deflection. Blocks are done while the staff person is
stationary. Staff 1 however, moved toward the youth and pushed
her against the wall, which is not considered a block. Staff 1 also
admitted she pushed Youth C into her room. Pushing a youth on
any part of their body is prohibited.
Video shows Staff 1 body-block Youth C as the youth tries to
move past her. Staff 1 said she blocked her to prevent her from
attacking Youths B and Y who were mocking her. However, a
fight between youths was not imminent. Body-blocking the
youth’s movement was unjustified.
In her room, Youth C claimed Staff 1 grabbed her arm, pushed her
and hit her head “really hard” on the wall. Staff 1 denied grabbing
Youth C’s arm, pushing her or hitting her head on the wall in the
bedroom. She admitted to pushing Youth C into her room and
Youth C falling onto the bed. There are no cameras inside of the
bedrooms.
The entire situation was unnecessary and could have been
avoided. It started only because Staff 1 decided it was too early
for Youth C to be out of her room and Youth C would not follow
her directive to return to her room.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
This incident occurred the morning of 6/14/23. CA was aware of it
that same day but did not view the video until investigators asked
her to do so on 6/16/23. CA told us other individuals at
Genacross monitor the videos, but it was unclear when they view
5

it and what they monitor for. I emphasized the importance of CA
proactively viewing video of known incidents particularly those that
relate to allegations of abuse/neglect on the part of staff. It
seemed lost on her that she is responsible for looking into
situations and developing timely safety/separation plans to protect
children when potential abuse has occurred. In another
investigation that commenced on 5/31/23 wherein three staff were
suspected of abuse, CA also did not assess those situations or
staff timely to decide if they were safe to continue working pending
the outcome. The facility was recently cited in SIR
2023C0000532 for CA failing to assess staff situations in a timely
manner potentially placing children at risk.
CONSULTATION
Staff 1 was inside a room alone with Youth C twice for 18 and 52
seconds. When youths are escalated or aggressive, it is
inadvisable for staff to be alone with them particularly in enclosed
areas out of view of the cameras.
Adrian Group Home is a small to mid-sized group home with a
capacity of ten. It is owned and run by parent-agency Genacross.
Genacross employs a number of administrative staff who work off-
site and perform roles in positions unregulated by Division of Child
Welfare Licensing (DCWL). Genesis refers to these non-
regulated staff as Supervisor of Group Homes, Trainer, HR
Officer, Hiring Manager, Manager of Compliance, Director of
Operations and Rights Officer. Throughout the course of this
investigation, state investigators received emails directly from
individuals in non-regulated positions such as HR Officer,
Manager of Compliance and Director of Operations.
The Chief Administrator and Licensee Designee are positions
regulated by the licensing agency. With multiple state
investigators entering the facility, it is helpful if the point of contact
is limited to these one or two individuals for accountability
purposes and to cut down on confusion. The main contact person
works on-site and is usually the Chief Administrator or designee.
One or both must be available and have the ability to provide
timely information to investigators upon request. State
investigators cannot be expected to know or understand the
organizational hierarchy of the parent agency or work with multiple
individuals in non-regulated positions at Genacross. Conversely,
as the person ultimately responsible for the facility, it is expected
the Chief Administrator be thoroughly knowledgeable of the
licensing rules, Adrian Group Home policies, MDHHS
policies/contract requirements and be heavily involved in internal
6

matters such as intake/admissions, assessing and assuring
quality, writing corrective action plans, accessing, viewing, and
analyzing video, hiring/training/disciplining staff and much more.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2023C0000500 intake 5/31/23; CAP pending
Rule Code & Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (4) Only the least restrictive intervention necessary to prevent
immediate harm to the youth or others may be used and must
follow an individualized set of graduated interventions that avoid
the use of restraints.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 1 engaged in a verbal power struggle with Youth C that
became physical.
Investigation Youth C woke up, came out of her room, and wanted to stay out of
her room around 8am. Staff 1 wanted her to go back in her room
and stay there until 9am which is when dayshift staff arrive. Staff
1 engaged in a verbal power struggle trying to get Youth C to
return to her room when being out of her room caused no harm to
herself or others. During this unnecessary verbal back and forth,
Staff 1 said Youth C hit her. While it is possible Youth C hit her,
there were no witnesses, it could not be seen on the video and
Staff 1 did not write an incident report indicating she was hit by the
youth. The verbal power struggle between Youth C escalated to a
physical one where Staff 1 pushed Youth C and briefly pinned her
against the wall. The entire situation could have been avoided
had Staff 1 merely allowed Youth C to be out of her room when
she was ready to start her day.
Analysis Staff 1 engaged in a verbal power struggle when the youth was
causing no harm to herself or others. The situation escalated to a
physical one. Least restrictive interventions were not utilized.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000228 intake 2/8/23, CAP approved 4/13/23
Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
7

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation There was no incident report describing the interaction that
occurred between Staff 1 and Youth C on 6/14/23.
Investigation The agency’s incident report policy indicates a non-critical incident
report should be written for physical acting out; not leading to
restraint.
There was no incident report describing the interaction that
occurred between Staff 1 and Youth C on 6/14/23 between 8 –
8:30am. Staff 1 said Youth C hit her and the video showed a
physical struggle between the staff and the youth in the hall. Staff
1 and Youth C were alone together in a room and Staff 2 heard
Youth C say Staff 1 pushed her.
Analysis Per agency policy, Staff 1 should have written an incident report
describing the interaction between her and Youth C on the
morning of 6/14/23.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000500 intake 5/31/23; CAP pending.
2023C0000538 intake 6/13/23; CAP pending.
Rule Code & Rule 400.4112 Staff qualifications.
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 1 does not have the ability to perform her assigned duties.
Investigation Due to Staff 1’s behavior, Government Worker 1 confirmed a case
against her deeming her unsuitable to work with children.
Analysis Government Worker 1 deemed Staff 1 unsuitable to work with
children.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000500 intake 5/31/23; CAP pending

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
